metadata.name: Bound #7
metadata.description:
Knots bind and hold, mark time, and unite. But the power of a well-tied knot isn't only to fasten – it also symbolizes how tightly one holds their pledges. Whether a commitment to a partner, community, or oneself – the longevity of a deeply held bond is often marked with a symbol of passing time, like knots tied in a rope.

Let these ropes remind us of the binds we hold – new ones, lengthy ones, unbreakable ones, and even those we’ve had to untie. In plain view, these knots invite us to contemplate what our bonds mean to us, and to see them anew.

---

Press ‘1’-’9’ to increase resolution
Press 's' to save an image of the output at the current resolution

Created with p5.js
For third party license information, please see license.md

---

TENDER x David Brice Allen
July 2022

metadata.name: interference x resonance #285
metadata.description:
M: "Have you noticed that every day is like every other day, somewhat?" 

T: "Yes, I've noticed that" 

M: "And have you noticed that every week is more or less like every other week?" 

T: "Yes..."

M: "Well, did you know that every day has a relationship to four other days. And they are not the four days preceding it. They are scattered back through time. One of them may be six months in the past, one of them may be thousands of years in the past, but each day is actually an interference pattern caused by the resonant... the coming together of the resonances of other times."

T: "...I mean... it's a weird idea. It NEVER occurred to me that that was a possibility."

-- Terence McKenna, ethnobotanist, psychonaut, and noted boundary-pusher

The story above was an inspiration for this generative artwork. To me, art is about communicating ideas, ideas that sometimes fall outside of the boundaries of our normal, culturally-sanctioned model of reality. 

This work is about the interconnectedness of all things. It's about the repeating patterns and echoes, both seen and unseen, that impact the world around us and our experience of it. How things are always the same and yet not the same, different and yet not different. And it's a reminder to always question what you think you know.

metadata.name: Growth v02 #452
metadata.description:
Growth patterns, version 2. January 2022
Edition of 512

Growth v02 is an generative exploration of patterns in the style of William Morris' iconic wallpaper designs from the 1800s. The code for the Growth series was originally designed to create plausible road networks but has been rewritten to create more organic curved forms. Created with p5js.

'space' to pause the simulation
'h' to toggle to higher res (increases canvas size but runs slower: great for screengrabs)
'r' to reset the seed (some features are locked to the original hash)
's' to save an image to disk
All generated patterns are tile-able horizontally and vertically.

Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

This project relies heavily on randomly generated values. It has been thoroughly tested. However, there is always the chance that the wrong combination of randomness can create less-compelling growth. If you feel you version is not living up to the potential promised with this piece, please email me.

Thank You

Created with love for p5js and generative art

@Qotonana
July, 2022.

metadata.name: SoulSea #46
metadata.description:
The Soul Sea

You look down and find that the ocean in your heart is a sine wave. 
The tide gently laps onto the shore.

The soul is the sea. You are the land. 
There are waves on the shore, and the waves are slices.

Gazing at the slices, you feel the coldness of the Arctic Ocean, the permafrost of the Antarctic Sea, the deep darkness of the bottomless sea.

Stay silent, hear the sound of the waves lapping at the innumerable shores far away.
Feel the soul of the digital ocean.

Interactivities:
> Key P: Pause
> Key S: Save
> Press and move mouseX: wave moves slower / faster

Che-Yu Wu

metadata.name: Solace #142
metadata.description:
Solace is an algorithm that generates artworks of sand dunes. It draws hundreds of thousands of tiny points according to a probability distribution calculated from the positions of the dunes.

The logic to divide the dunes into light and dark sides is simple, but produces some interesting chaotic behaviour. These are details that weren't hard-coded but emerge organically, such as the patterns on the spines of the dunes or the stripes around their bases.

Please note that the algorithm can take some time to run, especially when the number of dunes is high.

Created by lunarean.

metadata.name: Incomplete Convergence #280
metadata.description:
Cutting an optimization process short can lead to interesting results. This series builds on the earlier Sneronoi series but doesn't attempt to run to full convergence. Images are generated by gradient descent and the optimization process is shown as an animation. Each piece is considered final when the animation stops.

There are ten different color palettes, each with four different options for background colors. There are also different shapes drawn in the background and different modes in which the foreground and the background are blended together. In combination, these options result in a wide range of distinct visual outputs. Made with D3.

Press 's' to save as svg.

Press 'p' to save as png (4000x4000).

Author:
Claus O. Wilke
https://clauswilke.com/art
https://twitter.com/clauswilke

metadata.name: Tezumie 1-1 #596
metadata.description:
Tezumie have found themselves in Dimension 1-1, the perfect place for an adventure!

-WARNING-
They may seem to be a cute companion to hang out in your browser, but DO NOT leave them there for extended periods.  

Side effects may include: Missing items in your household, odd behavior in pets, a strange odor, prolonged nightmares, restless leg syndrome, hearing colors, missing teeth, uncontrollable urges, existential crisis, temporary blindness, and a strong appetite for non-edible objects.

Special Thanks to the following creators for permitting traits based on their art/style/projects;

AgataPoison, Craigers , griza, iRyanBell, Jim the Bim, KilledByAPixel, Liam Egan, Littlesilver, lucky26, MarkKnol, ozzie, PersonChen, punevyr, and the creators of MIME x MIME.

-CONTROLS-
(W)-Toggle weather
(F)-Toggle frame 
(C)-Toggle cursor
(P)–Pause
(A)-Shrink
(D)-Grow
(SHIFT + S)-Save image
(SHIFT + G)-Save 4 frames that you can use to make a GIF, see “sketch.js” for further instructions.

Made in p5js.

metadata.name: GuilCity #124
metadata.description:
GuilCity is the beginning of an exciting journey bringing Guillaume Cornet’s densely-packed cities into the generative realm with the help of Matthew’s (@frostbitten’s) magic touch.

Matthew—with his background in coding and animation—enables a new opportunity to experience these cities like never before. Numerous elements from vehicles to characters and even architecture have been given life. Interact with the city (computer mouse only): poke and peek around (even behind) in this active search & find journey! 

Each generative city fills the composition with the type of whimsical, expressive elements and characters you’ve come to know Guil for. What kinds of wacky features have you discovered yet?

—

The tech behind this project utilizes the highly compressed WEBP image format in order to provide so many full-color options. This format is great, but unfortunately Safari on desktop/laptop must be upgraded to at least version 14 and macOS to at least version 11 Big Sur to use it.

The animation system for this project was created from scratch with additional help from the PIXI.js library for individual mesh animations.

—

To find out more about your GuilCity, copy your unique operation hash and place it at the end of the following url:
• https://my.guil.city?fxhash=
(for example: https://my.guil.city?fxhash=ooezL8cffNJGSc4TfNQp3u3WnDpkg8J3zFRczLuumceoYU5QYPs)

—


The entire process has been a learning experience for both of us, adapting and exploring the many possibilities to interact with each others’ skills and ideas.

We really enjoyed building this project together and are excited as we invite you to take a dive into your very own urban playground!

Merci à tous! Cheers!
  - Guillaume Cornet, Matthew Seremet

metadata.name: Stacked Mondrian #13
metadata.description: Stacked Mondrian is a collaboration between Benjamin & George, Which was inspired in the Piet Mondrian style. Every piece is unique and each one transmits a different form of expression of one true self.

metadata.name: a house divided #107
metadata.description:
This piece reuses the same line drawing algorithm from 'this is where i draw the line', meant to emulate a marker drawing on paper.

In terms of composition, we start with a single square, which we divide into two rectangles, either horizontally or vertically. We then repeat this process some number of times for each of the resulting rectangles. Finally, we fill the rectangles by drawing them with lines. These lines
can be either straight or curved.

The collection of inks and papers has also been expanded from 'this is where i draw the line'. Collectors of that piece have been placed on the reserve list as a thank you for their support.

This piece was created using p5.js

metadata.name: BULLET #17
BULLET #47
Action Painting #43
metadata.description:
In homage to Jackson Pollock. An algorithmic version of Action Painting.

My Fractions of the Whole algorithm organizes the space frame into areas for a tile comprised of closed paths of bezier line segments with random parameters. An underlying layer is tessellated with tiles made up of closed pathways are filled with a random color; that simulates the chance effects of dripping and spilling paint onto a canvas. Simulating the moving brush-in-hand, nine more iterations the image are overdrawn, each in separate random color, where the shapes are in outline (not filled). The result is a highly dynamic image that simulates the direct, instinctual, and spontaneous application of vigorous, sweeping lines of color.  

Check out Dr. Bill Generative Art OG website @ drbillkolomyjec.com
